messages.content:
faça um script pra vc funcionar no automatico
Current File Path:
```markdown
c:\Users\endri\HAWZX\HAWZX_AI_Guide.md
```

Entendido. Para criar um script de automação, preciso primeiro entender o que o projeto HAWZX faz e como seus componentes funcionam juntos.

Vou começar analisando os scripts de compilação e inicialização existentes e a configuração do Docker para entender o fluxo de trabalho atual do backend. Vou usar o `codebase_investigator` para essa tarefa.

thoughts.subject: Understanding Automation Requests
thoughts.description: I'm now focusing on what "funcionar no automático" truly implies. It seems like the user desires a script, and I'm parsing the possible meanings. Is the objective to automate my own creation, a potentially complex, meta task? Or, more probably, to automate the execution of the HAWZX-AI project? My analysis leans towards the latter scenario as the more plausible interpretation.

thoughts.subject: Deciphering Automation Intent
thoughts.description: I've refined the automation request's interpretation. Analyzing the `HAWZX-AI` project directory, I've identified key files. The user probably wants a script to handle the whole application stack, given the directory structure and the presence of `docker-compose.yml`. My focus shifts to crafting a script that efficiently orchestrates the various components, likely beginning with the infra scripts. I'm taking the Windows environment of the powershell scripts into account.

thoughts.subject: Devising the Automation Blueprint
thoughts.description: My current thinking pivots to the project's orchestration. Given the files present, and the "funcionar no automático" directive, I plan to develop a script that acts as the control center for the whole application stack. This script will sequentially handle dependency installation, backend build and start-up using provided scripts, and then the launch of the frontend and desktop components. A comprehensive plan is now forming, centered on a unified script to manage these processes.

thoughts.subject: Crafting the Orchestration Script
thoughts.description: I'm now zeroing in on the architecture of the automation script. My plan is now fully formed, and I'll now examine the `infra` scripts, specifically `build-backend.ps1` and `start-backend.ps1`, to inform how the main orchestration script should be constructed. I will integrate the use of the `docker-compose.yml` to make the solution more flexible. Following this, I will draft the dependency installation, backend build and start-up steps, and the launch sequence for the frontend and desktop components.

messages.content: O `codebase_investigator` demorou muito. Vou ler os arquivos manualmente para criar o script de automação. Começarei com `infra/build-backend.ps1` para entender o processo de compilação do backend.

thoughts.description: I am now delving into the core project files. Initially, I'll examine `infra/build-backend.ps1` to understand its role. Next, I plan to move on to `infra/start-backend.ps1` to learn about backend startup and then investigate the Docker compose setup. From there, I'll review other files to grasp the entire project.

thoughts.description: Now that I've fixed the file path, I'm ready to move on. I'm compiling a list of files I need to examine to craft the automation script. I see that it anticipates a virtual environment in the `.venv` directory. I'm moving on to the next file to continue the analysis.

thoughts.subject: Outlining Script's Purpose
thoughts.description: I've just drafted the `run-hawzx.ps1` script and am now strategizing how best to communicate its functionality and usage to the user. I'm focusing on clarity and conciseness to ensure the explanation is easily understood.

messages.content: I messed up. I tried to use `run_shell_command` to display a file, which is wrong. I should have just explained the `run-hawzx.ps1` script. It automates the HAWZX-AI project setup by checking for Python and Node, setting up the backend and desktop dependencies, then launching the FastAPI server and Electron app. To use it, you just run `.\run-hawzx.ps1` in PowerShell from the project root. The backend will be at `http://localhost:8000`. I will explain this now.

I'm now focused on crafting a clear explanation of what the script accomplishes, which is the correct approach. I intend to provide a succinct description of the script's function to the user.

thoughts.subject: Outlining Script Functionality
thoughts.description: My focus has shifted. I am now detailing the actions the `run-hawzx.ps1` script performs. I've broken down its purpose: setting up the HAWZX-AI project, checking dependencies, and launching the backend and desktop app. I plan to provide clear, actionable instructions on execution.

messages.content: I created `run-hawzx.ps1` to automate the project. It first checks for Python and Node.js. Then, it sets up the backend by creating a virtual environment and installing packages from `requirements.txt`. Next, it installs npm dependencies for the desktop app. Finally, it launches the backend server in the background and, after a 5-second delay, starts the Electron application. I'll now explain this to the user.

thoughts.subject: Defining Script Functionality
thoughts.description: I'm now detailing the script's core purpose. The user required a script for project automation, and I've crafted a PowerShell script named `run-hawzx.ps1`. My focus is on clearly explaining its functionality, since direct display was initially blocked.

thoughts.subject: Explaining Script Actions
thoughts.description: I'm presently outlining the script's actions in detail. The user requires a script for project automation. My PowerShell script, `run-hawzx.ps1`, is designed to handle this. It will check dependencies (Python, Node.js), set up both the backend (Python virtual environment, package installations) and desktop app (Node.js dependencies), and then launch everything. This involves backend server initialization and Electron application startup, too.

I'll then provide instructions on how to run it, and my task will be complete.

The script systematically checks for dependencies, namely Python and Node.js. It then sets up the Python virtual environment and installs backend components, followed by setting up the Node.js dependencies for the desktop application.
